Every time Elizabeth looked at her daughter, all she saw was her late fiancé. Ian had died in an avalanche while skiing in the Colorado backcountry when Madelyn was just a baby. The tragedy had plunged Elizabeth (identified in this story by first name only) into single parenthood, changing diapers, making meals, doing the bedtime routine all by herself, all while trying to bring in what money she could as a massage therapist. She struggled to find a place to live that felt like home: She moved with her daughter 15 times in just six years. By then, Elizabeth was so stressed that she was smoking weed to get to sleep, and she knew that it was only a matter of time until Madelyn noticed how traumatized her mother was. Seeing pieces of Ian in her daughter’s face could trigger “the most acute pain I’ve ever been in,” Elizabeth told me. “I knew that I had to figure it out. I was gonna get my shit together. My kid depended on it.”
